content:
Amendment: 2

decided whether the second amendment protected an individual right to keep a [fire]arm for self-defense
conclusion: the second amendment is an individual right intimately tied to the natural right of self-defense

based on a 1975 law in DC that restricted residents from owning handguns excluding those grandfathered in by registration prior to 1975 and those possessed by active and retired law enforcement
also required that all firearms including rifles and shotguns be kept unloaded and disassembled or something else
	many challenged the law and, because of the controversial nature of the case that harbored much attention to many groups on both sides of the gun rights issue, the court ultimately argued that the second amendment protects an individual right to possess a firearm unconnected to service of in the militia and to use that arm for traditionally lawful purposes, such as self-defense within the home
	like most rights, the second amendment is not unlimited; it's not the right to keep and carry any weapon whatsoever and any _ whatsoever and for whatever purpose
